page.title: 07Communications,Wick
page.content: Wick radio station,taken over by the Post Office in 1922,is very important because it covers an area extending to 300 miles east of Wick.The annual running cost is about half a million pounds. In the last 20 years,the radio station has changed considerably.It used to have most of its calls from fishing boats but now they come from oil rigs in the North Sea.Many messages come through in foreign languages. There are six masts,some receivers and some transmitters.Some of the smaller receivers are being replaced by a larger one.The radio station also has a telex system,where messages are printed out instead of being spoken. One of the machines they have is a back up generator,which is used in winter,when there is a power cut.
